title: Will Vladimir Putin or Donald Trump host the other for an official bilateral visit before 1 October 2017?

In light of the expulsion of U.S. diplomats from Russian, the likelihood of diplomatic meetings would, at the surface, seem to be diminished.  But, the effect of POTUS signing the new Russian sanctions bill may in fact spur discussion over how to better handle the relationship between the two countries.  I admit, that consequence seems unlikely to manifest, particularly with the Trump-Russia issues that permeate every facet of U.S. politics these days.  That being considered, Trump has an incentive - maintaining a semblance of credibility and deniability in the face of U.S. media - to avoid direct interaction with Russia at all costs if it has any potential to be construed as favoring Russia.  On the other hand, Putin would seem to have a small incentive to engage with the U.S. given both these new sanctions and the Pentagon's recent indication that it was prepared to get involved in Ukraine in some capacity.  Add in Russia's planned military exercises on NATO boarders, and you have a situation that is ripe for disaster and also prime for discussion.  Thus, although Trump would lose political capital by reaching out, Putin would not and would stand to gain in the eyes of the international community bu reaching out before any military action (exercises or otherwise) came to bear.  For these reasons, I believe there is a slight, but unlikely, chance that a bilateral visit could occur.
